explanation:
- lfs_dir_find: The call lfs_dir_find(lfs, &cwd.m, &path, &id) passes the address of the local parameter 'path'. To determine whether lfs_mkdir_ violates MISRA (modifying a function parameter), we must know whether lfs_dir_find writes through that pointer (i.e. changes *(&path) which modifies the local parameter variable 'path').
- lfs_dir_fetchmatch, lfs_dir_get, lfs_tag_type3, lfs_tag_id, lfs_pair_fromle32: These are direct callees (or helpers) used by lfs_dir_find per the static call graph. lfs_dir_find may delegate pointer advancement or writes to these helpers, so their implementations are needed to determine if any of them (directly or indirectly via lfs_dir_find) perform writes that change the caller's 'path' variable.
- lfs_path_islast and lfs_path_namelen: These are used immediately after lfs_dir_find on the (possibly modified) path. Including them helps confirm whether those functions expect a const pointer and only read from the string (they do not take a pointer-to-pointer), and to understand whether lfs_mkdir_ relies on path being advanced by lfs_dir_find. Together these symbols allow the analyzer to decide if the parameter variable 'path' itself is being modified (a MISRA violation) or only the object it points to is being touched (allowed).
